\begin{abstract}

The size Ramsey number $ \hat{r}(G,H) $ of two graphs $ G $ and $ H $ is the smallest integer $ m $ such that there exists a graph $ F $ on $ m $ edges with the property that every red-blue colouring of the edges of $ F $, yields a red copy of $ G $ or a blue copy of $ H $.
In $ 1981 $, Erd\H{o}s observed that
$\hat{r}(K_{1,k},K_{3})\leq \binom{2k+1}{2}-\binom{k}{2}$ and he conjectured that the corresponding upper bound on $ \hat{r}(K_{1,k},K_{3}) $ is sharp.
In $ 1983 $, Faudree and Sheehan extended this conjecture as follows:
\begin{eqnarray*}
\hat{r}(K_{1,k},K_{n})=\left \{
\begin{array}{lr}
\binom{k(n-1)+1}{2}-\binom{k}{2} & ~k\geq n~ \text{or}~ k~ \text{odd}.\\
\\
\binom{k(n-1)+1}{2}-k(n-1)/2 & \text{otherwise}.
\end{array} \right.
\end{eqnarray*}
They proved the case $ k=2 $. In $ 2001 $, Pikhurko showed that this conjecture is not true for $ n=3 $ and
$ k\geq 5 $, disproving the mentioned conjecture of Erd\H{o}s. Here we prove Faudree and Sheehan's conjecture for a given $ k $
when\linebreak $ n\geq k^3-k+4 $ and also the case when $ k=3 $.\\
\noindent{\textbf{Keywords:} Ramsey number, Size Ramsey number, Restricted size Ramsey number.}\\
{\small AMS subject classification: 05C55, 05D10.}

\end{abstract}







\section{Introduction}

\bigskip

Given two graphs $ G $ and $ H $, we say that $ F\longrightarrow (G,H) $,
if for any red-blue colouring of the edges of $ F $ we have a red copy of $ G $ or a blue copy of $ H $.
The {\it size Ramsey number} $ \hat{r}(G,H) $ of two graphs $ G $ and $H$ is the minimum number of edges of a graph $ F $ such that $ F\longrightarrow (G,H) $. Using this notation, the {\it Ramsey number} $r(G,H)$ is the minimum integer
$n$ such that $K_{n}\longrightarrow (G,H)$.
We also define the {\it restricted size Ramsey number} $\hat{r}^{*}(G,H)$ for two graphs $G$ and $H$ as follows:
\begin{eqnarray*}
\hat{r}^{*}(G,H)=min\{\vert E(F) \vert : F\longrightarrow (G,H), \vert V(F) \vert =r(G,H)\}.
\end{eqnarray*}
Clearly for every two graphs $G$ and $H$, we have $ \hat{r}(G,H) \leq \hat{r}^{*}(G,H) $.
Also, by the definition of $r(G,H)$, we have
$K_{r(G,H)}\longrightarrow (G,H)$.
Since the complete graph on $ r(G,H) $
vertices has
$ r(G,H) \choose 2 $
edges, we obtain trivially
\begin{eqnarray}\label{1}
\hat{r}(G,H)\leq {r(G,H)\choose 2}.
\end{eqnarray}
Chv\'{a}tal showed that equality holds in (\ref{1}), when $ G $ and $ H $ are complete graphs (see\cite{3}).\\


The investigation of the size Ramsey numbers of graphs was initiated by
Erd\H{o}s, Faudree, Rousseau and Schelp \cite{3} in $1978$.
In this paper, we investigate the size Ramsey number of $K_{1,k}$, the star with $k$ edges,
versus the complete graph $K_{n}$. These numbers were first considered by
Erd\H{o}s et al. \cite{3}. They showed the following asymptotic result:
\begin{theorem} \label{thm1}{\rm \cite{3}}
Let $\varepsilon$ be a fixed real number satisfying $ 0<\varepsilon<1  $ and let $n\geq 3$ be a fixed natural number. If $k$ is sufficiently large, then
\begin{eqnarray*}
\hat{r}(K_{1,k},K_{n})\geq \max \{k^{2}/2, (1-\varepsilon) \lfloor (n-2)^{2}/4\rfloor k^{2}/2\}.
\end{eqnarray*}
\end{theorem}
\noindent In \cite{2}, Erd\H{o}s observed that
$K_{k+1}+\overline{K}_{k}\longrightarrow (K_{1,k},K_{3})$ and conjectured that the corresponding upper bound on $ \hat{r}(K_{1,k},K_{3}) $ is sharp (where the graph $ K_{k+1}+\overline{K}_{k} $ is obtained from $ K_{k+1} $ by considering $ k $ new vertices and joining each vertex of $ K_{k+1} $ to all these $ k $ additional vertices).
Faudree and Sheehan generalized this result and showed that:
\begin{theorem}\label{thm2} {\rm \cite{4}}
Let $k,n\geq 2 $, then
\begin{eqnarray*}
\hat{r}^{*}(K_{1,k},K_{n})=\left \{
\begin{array}{lr}
\binom{k(n-1)+1}{2}-\binom{k}{2} & ~k\geq n~\text{or}~ k~ \text{odd},\\
\\
\binom{k(n-1)+1}{2}-k(n-1)/2 & ~\text{otherwise}.
\end{array} \right.
\end{eqnarray*}
\end{theorem}
\noindent
They also posed the following conjecture:
\begin{conjecture}\label{conj1} {\rm \cite{4}}
Let $k,n \geq 2$. Then $\hat{r}(K_{1,k},K_{n})=\hat{r}^{*}(K_{1,k},K_{n})$.
\end{conjecture}
\noindent
They proved the case $k=2$ of this conjecture (see \cite{4}). Pikhurko \cite{7}, with a nice counterexample, disproved the
Erd\H{o}s conjecture for $ k \geq 5 $ (the case $ n=3 $ of Conjecture \ref{conj1}).
More precisely, he showed that $ \hat{r}(K_{1,k},K_{3})<k^{2}+\sqrt{2}k^{3/2}+k $ for $ k\geq 1 $. One can easily check that  for $ k\geq 5 $,
\begin{eqnarray*}
k^{2}+\sqrt{2}k^{3/2}+k < \binom{2k+1}{2}-\binom{k}{2}.
\end{eqnarray*}
Also, Pikhurko \cite{8} showed that for any graph $ F $ with chromatic number $ \chi(F)\geq 4 $,
\begin{eqnarray*}
\hat{r}(K_{1,k}, F)\leq \chi(F)\big(\chi(F)-2\big)k^{2}/2 +o(k^{2})
\end{eqnarray*}
and conjectured that this is sharp. He proved his conjecture for the case $ \chi(F)=4 $.\\

\noindent
In this paper, we show that for a fixed $k\geq 2$, Conjecture \ref{conj1}
holds for sufficiently large $n$. More precisely, we demonstrate that:
\begin{theorem} \label{thm3}
Let $ k\geq 2 $ and $n \geq k^{3}-k+4$. Then
$\hat{r}(K_{1,k},K_{n})=\hat{r}^{*}(K_{1,k},K_{n})$.
\end{theorem}
Moreover, we prove Conjecture \ref{conj1} for $ k=3 $.\\


\noindent
\textbf{Conventions and Notations:}
For a graph $ G $, we write $ V(G) $,  $ E(G) $ and $ e(G) $ for the vertex set, edge set and the number of edges of $ G $, respectively.
For $ u,v \in V(G)$, we write $ u\sim v $ if $ u $ is adjacent to $ v $ and $ u\nsim v $ where
$ u $ is nonadjacent to $ v $.
For $ v \in V(G) $, by $ N_{G}(v) $ we mean the set of all neighbours of $ v $ and the degree $ d_{G}(v) $ of $ v $ is
$ d_{G}(v)=\vert N_{G}(v) \vert $. We denote by
$ \delta(G) $ and $ \Delta(G) $ the minimum and maximum degrees of $ G $, respectively.
Let $ X\subseteq V(G) $. Then $ G[X] $ is the induced subgraph of $ G $ with vertex set $ X $. We write $ G\setminus X $ for $ G[V(G)\setminus X] $.
Let $ A,B \subset V(G) $, then $ e(A,B)=\vert \{ \{x,y\}\in E(G) : x\in A, y\in B\}\vert $,
is the number of edges connecting a vertex of $ A $ to a vertex of $ B $.
 By $ \overline{G} $ we mean the complement of $ G $.\\

\section{Preliminaries}
In this section, we present some results that we will use in the follow up sections. The following lemma is a modified version of Lemma
$ 1 $ in \cite{4}. The proof is similar to that of [$ 4 $, Lemma $ 1 $]. But for the sake of completeness, we state it's proof here.
\begin{lemma}\label{lem1} {\rm \cite{4}}
Let $ k \geq 2 $ and G be a graph with $ e(G) \geq \binom{k}{2}+1 $. Then either \vspace{0.2 cm}\\
$ (i) $ G contains an induced subgraph with $ k+1 $ vertices and minimum degree at least\\
\indent $ 1 $ or\\
$ (ii) $ G contains a matching $ M $ with $ \vert M \vert=e(G)$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
We use induction on $ k $. The case $ k=2 $ is easily verified. Suppose that $ k\geq 3 $. If there is a vertex $ v\in V(G) $ so that
$ d_{G}(v)\geq k $, then the induced subgraph on $ N_{G}(v)\cup \{v\} $ has $ k+1 $ vertices with minimum degree at least one.
Hence we may assume that $ d_{G}(v)\leq k-1 $, for all $ v\in V(G) $. If for every $ v\in V(G) $, $ d_{G}(v)\leq 1 $, then proposition $ (ii) $ of Lemma $ 2.1 $ holds. Hence there is a vertex $ v\in V(G) $ so that
$ 2\leq d_{G}(v) \leq k-1$. Set $ G'=G\setminus \{v\} $. Clearly $ e(G')\geq e(G)-(k-1)\geq \binom{k-1}{2}+1 $. So by the induction hypothesis $ V(G') $ contains a subset $ Y $ so that, either\\
$ (a) $ $ \vert Y \vert=k $ and $ \delta(G'[Y])\geq 1 $, or\\
$ (b) $ $ G'[Y]\cong sK_2 $, so that $ s=e(G') $.\\
At first assume that $ N_{G}(v) \cap Y\neq \emptyset $. If $ Y $ is of type $ (a) $, then set $ X=Y\cup \{v\} $ and Lemma
$ 2.1(i) $ holds. So assume that $ Y $ is of type $ (b) $. If $ k $ is odd, then the set of $ k+1 $ vertices incident to some set of
$ (k+1)/2 $ disjoint edges contained in
$ G'[Y] $ satisfies Lemma $ 2.1(i) $. Now suppose that $ k $ is even and $ u\in N_{G}(v)\cap Y $. Let $ X $ be the set of
$ k $ vertices incident to $ k/2 $ disjoint edges in $ G'[Y] $ including an edge incident to $ u $. Clearly $ X\cup \{v\} $ satisfies Lemma $ 2.1(i) $.\\
Now assume that $ N_{G}(v)\cap Y=\emptyset $. Let $ v_1, v_2 \in N_{G}(v)$. First, suppose that $ Y $ is of type $ (b) $. If $ k $ is odd, then by an arguement similar to the previous paragraph we can find a subgraph in $ G $ with $ k+1 $ vertices and minimum degree at least $ 1 $. If $ k $ is even, then let $ X^* $ be the set of vertices incident to some subset of $ (k-2)/2 $ disjoint edges in $G'[Y]$. Set $ U=X^*\cup \{v, v_1, v_2\} $. Clearly $ G[U] $ satisfies Lemma $ 2.1(i) $.
So we may assume that $ Y $ is of type $ (a) $. Set $ X=(Y\setminus \{u\}) \cup \{v, v_1\} $, where $ u $ is an arbitrary vertex of $ Y $. If $ X $ doesn't satisfy Lemma $ 2.1(i) $, then there exists $ x\in X $ so that
$ d_{G[X]}(x)=0 $.
Since $ Y $ is of type $ (a) $, so $ x\in Y\setminus \{u\} $ and $ x\sim u $ in $ G $. So we conclude that each vertex $ u\in Y $ is incident to a vertex $ x\in Y $ so that $ d_{G[Y]}(x)=1 $. Hence, $ G'[Y] $ is a matching and $ k $ is even.
Now set $ U=X^* \cup \{v,v_1,v_2\} $ where $ X^* $ is the set of $ k $ vertices incident to $ (k-2)/2 $ disjoint edges in
$ G'[Y] $. Clearly $ G[U] $ satisfies Lemma $ 2.1(i) $. So we are done.
\end{proof}

$ \hspace*{13.6cm}\square $\\

The following result is an immediate consequence of Lemma \ref{lem1}.
\begin{corollary}\label{cor1} {\rm \cite{4}}
Let $ k\geq 3 $ and $ G $ be a graph with $ e(G) \geq \binom{k}{2}+1 $. If $ k $ is odd, then $G$ contains an induced subgraph with $ k+1 $ vertices and minimum degree at least $ 1 $.
\end{corollary}

\begin{remark}\label{rm1}
Let $ G $ be a graph so that $ G\longrightarrow (K_{1,k},K_{n}) $. If $ G $ is edge minimal, then each vertex of $ G $ must be in some clique $ K_{n} $. Otherwise, assume that some vertex $ v\in V(G) $ is not in any clique $ K_n $. Colour the edges of $G'=G\setminus \{v\} $ arbitrarily and extend this colouring to $ G $ by colouring the edges incident to $ v $ blue. Since $ v $ is not in any blue copy of $ K_n $, we have $ G'\longrightarrow (K_{1,k},K_n) $, which is a contradiction with the edge minimality of $ G $.
\end{remark}

\begin{lemma}\label{lm3}
Let $ n \geq k $ and $ G $ be a graph so that $ G\longrightarrow (K_{1,k},K_{n}) $. Then\linebreak
$ \delta(G) \geq k(n-k+1)-1$.
\end{lemma}
\begin{proof}
We give a proof by induction on $ n $. We may assume that $ G $ is edge minimal. The case $ n=k $ holds by Remark \ref{rm1}. Hence suppose that $ n>k $. Using Remark \ref{rm1}, we may assume that
$ \delta(G) \geq n-1 \geq k$. Let $ v \in V(G) $ and $ X $ be a subset of $ N_{G}(v) $ such that $ \vert X \vert=k $. Set
$ G^{*}=G\setminus X $. Colour $ G^{*}$ so that there is no red copy of $ K_{1,k} $ and extend this colouring to $ G $ by colouring the edges of $ G[X] $ red and all so far uncoloured edges blue. Then there is a blue copy of $ K_n $ containing at most
one vertex of $ X $. Hence $ G^* $ contains a blue copy of $ K_{n-1} $.
In the other words,\linebreak $ G^{*}\longrightarrow (K_{1,k},K_{n-1}) $. By the induction hypothesis we have
\begin{eqnarray*}
 \delta(G^{*})\geq k(n-1-k+1)-1=k(n-k)-1.
\end{eqnarray*}
Therefore,
\begin{eqnarray*}
d_{G}(v) \geq d_{G^{*}}(v)+k \geq k(n-k)-1+k=k(n-k+1)-1.
\end{eqnarray*}
So we are done.\\
\end{proof}
$ \hspace*{13.6cm}\square $

\section{The proof of Theorem \ref{thm3}}
Since $\hat{r}(K_{1,k},K_{n}) \leq \hat{r}^{*}(K_{1,k},K_{n})$, we shall prove just the lower bound for the claimed size Ramsey number. Set $ R=r(K_{1,k},K_{n})=k(n-1)+1 $. Let $ G $ be a graph with
$ R+l $, $ l\geq 0 $, vertices so that $ G \longrightarrow (K_{1,k},K_{n}) $. Our aim is to show that
$ e(G)\geq \hat{r}^{*}(K_{1,k},K_{n})$.\\
\\
Using Lemma \ref{lm3}, we have $ \delta(G) \geq k(n-k+1)-1 $.
So
\begin{eqnarray*}
e(G) =\dfrac{ \sum_{v \in G}{d_{G}(v)}}{2} \geq \dfrac{(R+l)(k(n-k+1)-1)}{2}~.
\end{eqnarray*}
One can easily check that if
$ l\geq k^{2}-2k+2 $, then $ e(G) \geq \hat{r}^{*}(K_{1,k},K_{n}) $. So we may assume that $ l\leq k^{2}-2k+1 $.
Suppose to the contrary that  $ G $ is a graph with
$ R+l $ vertices so that $ G \longrightarrow (K_{1,k},K_{n}) $ and $ e(G) < \hat{r}^{*}(K_{1,k},K_{n}) $.
Therefore, $ e(\overline{G}) \geq Rl+\binom{l}{2}+R'$, where
\begin{eqnarray*}
R'= \left \{
\begin{array}{lr}
\binom{k}{2}+1 & ~\text{if}~ k ~\text{is odd},\\
\\
k(n-1)/2+1 & \text{if} ~k ~\text{is even}.
\end{array} \right.
\end{eqnarray*}
We have the following claim.
\begin{claim}\label{clm1}
$ \overline{G} $ contains $ l+1 $ disjoint subsets
$ A_{1},\dots, A_{l+1} $ of vertices
so that for\linebreak
$ 1\leq i \leq l+1 $, $ \vert A_{i} \vert = k+1$ and $ \delta(\overline{G}[A_{i}])\geq 1 $.
\end{claim}
\noindent \textit{Proof of Claim} \ref{clm1}.
We use induction on $ l $. First let $ l=0 $. Using Lemma \ref{lem1} and Corollary \ref{cor1}
if there is no subset $ A_1 \subseteq V(\overline{G}) $ with $ \vert A_1 \vert=k+1$ and $ \delta(\overline{G}[A_1])\geq 1 $, then
we may assume that $ k $ is even
and $ \overline{G} $ contains a matching $ M $ with $ \vert M \vert= e(\overline{G}) $. But it is impossible, since
$ \vert V(\overline{G}) \vert =k(n-1)+1$. Therefore, assume that $ l\geq 1 $. Let
\begin{eqnarray*}
A=\{v \in V(\overline{G}) : d_{\overline{G}}(v)\geq (k+1)(l+1)\}.
\end{eqnarray*}
We have two following cases:\vspace*{0.5 cm}\\
\textbf{Case 1.}
$ A\neq \emptyset. $ \vspace*{0.5cm}\\
\noindent Set $ G'=\overline{G}\setminus \{v\} $, where $ v \in A $. Since $ d_{\overline{G}}(v)\leq R+l-1 $, we have
\begin{eqnarray*}
e(G') \geq R(l-1) +\binom{l-1}{2}+R'.
\end{eqnarray*}
By the induction hypothesis, $ G' $ contains $ l $ disjoint subsets
$ A_{1},\dots, A_{l} $ of vertices
so that for $ 1\leq i \leq l $, $ \vert A_{i} \vert = k+1$ and $ \delta(G'[A_{i}])\geq 1$. Choose
$ U\subseteq N_{\overline{G}}(v) \setminus \bigcup_{i=1}^{l}A_{i}$ so that $ \vert U \vert =k$
(note that, this is possible since $ d_{\overline{G}}(v) \geq (k+1)(l+1) $).
Clearly $ U \cup \{v\}$ is a new subset (disjoint from $ A_{i}s$ for $1\leq i\leq l $) of order $ k+1 $ and minimum degree at least
$ 1 $ in $ \overline{G} $. So we are done.\vspace*{0.5 cm}\\
\textbf{Case 2.}
$ A=\emptyset $.\vspace*{0.5cm}\\
\noindent Delete an arbitrary vertex $ v $ of $\overline{G}$ and use the induction hypothesis on $ \overline{G}\setminus \{v\} $. So
$ \overline{G} $
contains $ l $ disjoint subsets
$ A_{1},\dots, A_{l} $ of vertices
so that for $ 1\leq i \leq l $, $ \vert A_{i} \vert = k+1$ and $ \delta(\overline{G}[A_{i}])\geq 1$.\\

Set
$ \mathcal{A}=\bigcup_{i=1}^{l}A_{i} $ and $ G'=\overline{G}\setminus \mathcal{A} $.
Since each vertex of $ \overline{G} $ has degree less than $ (k+1)(l+1) $, we have
\begin{eqnarray*}
e(G') \geq Rl+\binom{l}{2}+R'-l(k+1)\big((l+1)(k+1)-1\big)+l(k+1)/2.
\end{eqnarray*}
Since $ n\geq k^{3}-k+4 $ and $ l\leq k^{2}-2k+1 $,
\begin{eqnarray*}
Rl+\binom{l}{2}+l(k+1)/2+l(k+1)-l(l+1)(k+1)^{2} \geq 0.
\end{eqnarray*}
So we have
$ e(G') \geq R' $.
If there exists a subset $ A_{l+1} $ of $ V(G') $ so that\linebreak
$ \vert A_{l+1}\vert=k+1 $ and
$ \delta(G'[A_{l+1}])\geq 1 $, then we are done.
So using Lemma \ref{lem1} and Corollary \ref{cor1} we may assume that $ k $ is even
and $ G' $ contains a matching $ M $ so that \linebreak
$ \vert M \vert= e(G') \geq k(n-1)/2+1 $. But it is impossible,
since
$ \vert V(G') \vert =k(n-l-1)+1$. Which completes the proof of our claim.\\
$ \hspace*{13.6 cm}\square $


Now consider the following colouring on $ G $. Partition $ V(G) $ into subsets\linebreak
$ X_{1},\dots, X_{n-1} $ so that $ X_{i}=A_{i} $ for $ 1\leq i \leq l+1 $ and $ \vert X_{i} \vert =k$ for
$ i=l+2,\dots, n-1 $.
Colour every edge of $ G[X_{i}] $ red $ (i=1,\dots,n-1) $ and all other edges of $ G $ blue. Then there is no red copy of
$ K_{1,k} $ and no blue copy of $ K_{n} $. Which is a contradiction with the assumption that
$ G\longrightarrow (K_{1,k},K_{n}) $.\\
$ \hspace*{13.6 cm}\square $

\section{$\hat{r}(K_{1,3},K_{n})$}
In this section, we prove the case $ k=3 $ of Conjecture \ref{conj1}. The following lemma is indeed Lemma
$ 3 $ of \cite{8}. But for the sake of completeness, we prove it here.
\begin{lemma}\label{bb}
If $ G $ is a graph so that $ G\longrightarrow (K_{1,k},K_{n}) $, then $ \Delta(G)\geq k(n-1) $.
\end {lemma}
\begin{proof}
Clearly for every $ (n-1)$-partitions of $ V(G) $ such as
$ V(G)=\bigcup_{i=1}^{n-1}A_{i} $,\linebreak
we have
\begin{eqnarray*}
\max  \{\Delta(G[A_{i}]) : 1\leq i\leq n-1\} \geq k.
\end{eqnarray*}
Otherwise, we can colour the edges of $ G[A_i] $ for $ 1\leq i \leq n-1 $, red and all so far uncoloured edges blue. Hence there is no red copy of $ K_{1,k} $ and no blue copy of $ K_n $, which is a contradiction.\\
Now consider a partition $ V(G)=\bigcup_{i=1}^{n-1}A_{i} $ which minimizes $ S=\sum_{i=1}^{n-1}{e(G[A_i])} $.
For some $ 1\leq i\leq n-1 $, there exists a vertex $ v\in G[A_i] $ so that $ d_{G[A_i]}(v)\geq k $.
If there is $ 1\leq j \leq n-1 $ with $ j\neq i $ so that $ d_{G[A_j]}(v)<k $, then moving $ v $ to $ A_j $ decreases $ S $. Therefore, $ d_{G[A_i]}(v)\geq k $ for every $ 1\leq i \leq n-1 $ and $\Delta(G)\geq d_{G}(v)\geq k(n-1) $.\\
\end{proof}
$ \hspace*{13.6cm}\square $\\
Now we prove the case $ k=3 $ of Conjecture \ref{conj1}.

\begin{theorem}
For $ n\geq 2 $, we have $ \hat{r}(K_{1,3},K_{n})=\hat{r}^{*}(K_{1,3},K_{n})=\binom{3(n-1)+1}{2}-3.$
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
We use induction on $ n $. The cases $ n=2 $ and $ n=3 $ are proved in \cite{aa}.
So we may assume that $ n\geq 4 $. Let
$ G $ be a graph so that $ G \longrightarrow (K_{1,3},K_{n}) $ and
\begin{eqnarray*}
\vert V(G) \vert\geq r(K_{1,3}, K_{n})+1=3n-1.
\end{eqnarray*}
It suffices to show that there is a subset $ A\subset V(G) $ so that $ 3 \leq \vert A \vert \leq 4$, $ \Delta(G[A])\leq 2 $ and
\begin{eqnarray*}
\alpha= e(G[A]) + e(A,G\setminus A)\geq 9n-12.
\end{eqnarray*}
To see that, let $ A $ be a subset of $ V(G) $ with the desired properties and $ G^{*}=G\setminus A $.
Colour $ G^{*} $ so that there is no red copy of $ K_{1,3} $ and
extend this colouring to $ G $ by colouring the edges of $ G[A] $ red and all so far uncoloured edges blue. Then there is a blue copy of
$ K_n $ containing at most one vertex of $ A $. Therefore,
$ G^{*}\longrightarrow (K_{1,3},K_{n-1}) $. Since $ \vert A \vert \leq 4 $, we have $ \vert V(G^{*}) \vert \geq 3(n-2)+1 $.
Now if $ \vert V(G^*) \vert=3(n-2)+1 $, then by Theorem \ref{thm2} and if $ \vert V(G^*) \vert=3(n-2)+2 $, then by the induction hypothesis, we have
\begin{eqnarray*}
e(G^{*}) \geq \binom{3(n-2)+1}{2}-3.
\end{eqnarray*}
Since $ \alpha \geq 9n-12 $, we have
\begin{eqnarray*}
e(G)\geq e(G^{*})+9n-12 \geq \binom{3(n-1)+1}{2}-3,
\end{eqnarray*}
and so we are done. Therefore, in the rest of the proof we will look for a subset $ A\subset V(G) $ with
$ \vert A \vert \in \{3,4\}$ and $ \Delta(G[A])\leq 2 $ so that $ \alpha \geq 9n-12 $. $ \vspace*{0.2 cm} $\\
\indent Using Lemma \ref{bb} we have $ \Delta(G) \geq 3(n-1) $. Let $ v_{1} $ be a vertex of $ G $ so that $ d_{G}(v_1)=\Delta(G) $.
